messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Ilja Preuss

> > - takes too long to run
> > completely in Eclipse before checking in;
>
> There are too solutions here:
>
> - don't always run them all,
> - speed them up

Good advice, and it gives me a good opportunity to stress the importance of
test groups.

It is important to group your tests in various categories, which can
represent several different things depending on your emphasis. For example,
you can have "database" tests, "front-end" tests, "security" tests, etc...

This kind of grouping is functional, but you can also have a more procedural
grouping: "check-in" tests (the tests that need to be run before any
submission to the depot), "functional" tests (which cover our entire
application", "integration" tests (making sure all the various parts work
well together), etc...

Obviously, one test can belong to several tests.

The only way you can group tests with JUnit is -- like the "test" hack -- by
using Java features: class and package names.

It was good enough back then because there was no choice, but we can do much
better now with annotations:

@Test(groups = { "check-in", "functional", "database" })
public void verifyAddressRecords() {
...
}

Notice how orthogonal your business logic is (method name and code) with how
this method will be interpreted with the test framework. There is no
interference: it's totally non-intrusive.

Once you have that, it becomes trivial to detach the static model (your test
code) from your runtime model (which tests to run) and it becomes much
easier to implement Ilja's suggestion: "don't always run them all".

If you have just modified some database-related code, you then need to

- Run all the "check-in" tests (mandatory for everyone)
- Run the "database" group (just to make sure)
